awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Flood volcanism and environmental impacts--multidisciplinary investigation of the Deccan Traps and events at the Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasing evidence suggests that the four most recent mass extinction events: end-Guadalupian; end-Permian; Triassic-Jurassic boundary; Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary (KPB)- are closely associated in time with continental flood basalt (CFB) volcanism. Paradoxically, the KPB is associated with both the Deccan Traps CFB and the Chicxulub impact in Yucatan, Mexico, engendering an intense three-decades-old debate over causal relationships. Deccan volcanism began well before and continued well after KPB/Chicxulub time, but the largest Deccan eruptions (Wai Sub-group) appear to have been initiated within ~50,000 years of both the KPB and the Chicxulub impact, suggesting that this subset of eruptions may have been triggered by the impact. It remains unclear whether large Deccan flood basalt eruptions or the Chicxulub impact (or both) were the cause of the KPB extinction, because both may have injected massive amounts of volatiles, aerosols, and particulates into the atmosphere. This project's research will improve our understanding of the genesis, timing, and environmental effects of Deccan Traps volcanism by considering Earth systems interactions from mantle plume convection to crustal magmatism to eruption and to atmosphere/biosphere effects. 

The research will include studies of: (1) The genesis and geodynamic context of Deccan magmatism based on physical volcanology and geochemical signatures, coupled with analysis of volatile contents; (2) Radioisotopic geochronology of the Deccan Traps to tightly constrain their eruptive tempo and relation to other KPB events; (3) Geophysical modeling of mantle and crustal magmatic processes, launching of volatiles and aerosols by the Deccan eruptions, and mechanisms of volcanic triggering by dynamic (seismic) stresses due to earthquakes and impacts; (4) Analysis of geophysical exploration data from offshore western India that has not previously been integrated into the main on-land Deccan stratigraphy. Results of these studies will be compared with other Phanerozoic CFB events, some of which are and, importantly, some of which are not associated with mass extinction.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project provided evidence that a massive episode of volcanism in India contributed to significant enrironmental changes leading up to mass extinction of non-avian dinosaurs 66 million years ago. The volcanism began at least 800 thousand years before the impact of a large meteoroid, but changed eruptive tempo and chemical composition likely due to effects of the impact. The main effects of the volcanism were probably due to gases that induced first warming and then cooling of the global climate, with the latter being enhanced by results of the impact itself.

Dating of the lavas composing the volcanic episode, collectively called the Deccan Traps, shows that the volcanic eruptions progressed from north to south, consistent with the motion of the Indian continent on a tectonic plate moving northward over a hot magma source (plume).

Analysis of the chemical composition of some of the lavas and the minerals that crystallized from them reveals that their source magmas resided at shallow depths, mostly less than 8 km, in the contintal crust prior to eruption.The data indicate that magma was erupted from muliple magma chambers rather than a single central vent.

A distinctive suite of lavas with huge (1-5 cm) crystals of the mineral plagioclase were erupted episodically, with eruptions from distinct magma chambers occurring simultaneously from conduits widely distributed around the 500 thousand square km Deccan Traps province. These eruptions were likely driven by release of gases from the magma, and may have been triggered by seismic energy from strong earthquakes produced in the Himalayan subduction zone.

Broader Impacts

Beyond the field of geology, the results of the project provide insight into the causes of mass extinctions, of interest in paleobiology. It also contributes to general public awareness of the importance of atmospheric gases in driving climate change and its collateral effects (i.e., mass extinction).

Through collaboration with Indian scientists, future projects such as participation in the analysis of samples obtained by scientific drilling are feasible. Additionally, a cooperation with the Indian National Oil and Gas Corporation is being discussed, which will enable extending this study into the now-submerged offshore component of the Deccan Traps in the Arabian Sea. This will enable a significantly more complete knowledge the evolution of the Deccan Traps.

Three PhD students (two female) participated in the project and received extensive experience in volcanology, geochemistry and geochronology for their dissertations. Two of these students have gained university faculty positions on the strength of their dissertations, and the third is currently finishing his PhD.
